data.source: Polling-station results from the Independent Election Commission (IEC) for the 2009 Afghanistan presidential election, ballot-box recount data from the Electoral Complaints Commission (ECC), declassified ISAF incident reports on violence, 2007 National Risk and Vulnerability Assessment (NRVA) household survey, LandScan population estimates, and GTOPO30 elevation data
data.wave_or_subset: 2009 Afghan presidential election; polling-station and district-level data merged with contemporaneous and prior violence measures
data.sample_size: Sample size of full IEC polling-station dataset not stated; recount subsample includes 342 ballot boxes across five fraud-risk strata; an illustrative field sample mentions 471 polling centres in 19 provincial capitals
data.unit_of_analysis: Primarily polling station; some analyses aggregated to district level
data.notes: Violence events were geo-referenced by matching settlement names to a gazetteer; population, elevation, and remoteness measures were merged to construct controls

method.description: The study applies forensic fraud detection to polling-station vote totals using the Beber–Scacco last-digit test, validates the fraud metric with a ballot-box recount, links the resulting fraud measure to geo-located data on insurgent violence, and estimates quadratic and spatial regression models to test how violence affects fraud by incumbent and challenger networks.
steps: Collect official polling-station vote totals from the IEC for the 2009 election.
Apply a chi-square test for uniformity of last digits of each candidate’s vote tallies at every station to flag suspicious results.
Construct a fraud indicator (and share of manipulated boxes) for each station or district based on p-values from the last-digit test.
Validate the forensic measure using results of an ECC-mandated manual recount of 342 ballot boxes.
Merge fraud measures with geo-coded violence data (ISAF incident reports) and socioeconomic covariates (NRVA, LandScan, elevation, distance to Kabul, electrification).
Estimate logit and OLS regressions including linear and squared terms for violence to test the inverted U-shaped hypothesis.
Estimate spatial displacement models incorporating violence in adjacent districts and candidate-specific fraud measures to compare incumbent (Karzai) versus challenger (Abdullah) networks.
Interpret coefficients and predicted values to evaluate hypotheses about violence–fraud relationships and network behaviour.
method.models: Chi-square goodness-of-fit tests for last-digit distribution; logit and OLS regression with quadratic terms; spatial lag models for adjacent-district violence effects
method.outcome_variable: Indicator or proportion of polling-station ballot boxes identified as fraudulent (based on last-digit test and validated recount)
method.independent_variables: Level of insurgent violence in the same district, squared term of violence, violence in adjacent districts (spatial lag), candidate identity (Karzai vs. Abdullah)
method.control_variables: Electrification rate, per-capita expenditure, distance to Kabul, elevation, number of closed stations, population density and other socioeconomic factors

results.summary: Regression estimates reveal an inverted U-shaped relationship between violence and electoral fraud: fraud increases with moderate violence but declines when violence is high. Fraud benefiting incumbent Karzai shows no spatial displacement, whereas fraud benefiting challenger Abdullah rises when neighbouring districts experience greater violence, indicating adaptive loyalty networks. Validation with a manual recount confirms that districts flagged by the last-digit test (Du Ab and Arghandab) contain a much higher share of manipulated ballot boxes than unflagged districts (e.g., Shindand).
